facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 24 of 1962 was filed as an appeal by special leave.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 24 of 1962. Appeal by special leave from the award dated November 23,

facts.text: Appeal is against the award dated November 23, 1960 of the Central Government Industrial Tribunal, Dhanbad in reference No. 31 of 1960.

anchor.surface_text: from the award dated November 23, 1960, of. the Central Government Industrial Tribunal, Dhanbad in reference No. 31 of 1960. C. Setalvad, Nonicoomar Chakravarty and B. P. Maheshwari, for the

facts.text: Judgment of the Court was delivered on January 23, 1963 by WANCHOO, J.

anchor.surface_text: 1963. January 23. The judgment of the Court was delivered by WANCHOO, J.-This is an appeal by special leave against the order of the Central Government Industrial T

facts.text: A dispute was referred by the Central Government under s.10 of the Industrial Disputes Act regarding thirteen workmen of Bhatdee Colliery.

anchor.surface_text: The brief facts necessary for present purposes are these. A dispute was referred by the Central Government under s, 10 of the Industrial Disputes Act, No. 14 of 1947,  hereinafter referred to as the Act  with reference to the thirteen workmen involved in this appeal in the following terms

facts.text: Reference terms: Whether the dismissal of the following thirteen workmen of Bhatdee Colliery was justified? If not, to what relief are they entitled and from which date?

anchor.surface_text: Whether the dismissal of the following thirteen workmen of Bhatdee Colliery, swa justified ? If number, to what relief are they entitled and from which date ? It appears that the thirteen workmen had physically obstructed the surface trammers working in the companyliery on different dates, namely October 20, October 27, and November 3,1959 .

facts.text: Thirteen workmen physically obstructed surface trammers on October 20, October 27, and November 3, 1959.

anchor.surface_text: It appears that the thirteen workmen had physically obstructed the surface trammers working in the companyliery on different dates, namely October 20, October 27, and November 3,1959 .some of them had also incited the other workmen to join in this act of obstructing the loyal and willing trammers so that they may be prevented from working.

facts.text: Some of the thirteen workmen incited other workmen to join in obstructing the loyal and willing trammers.

anchor.surface_text: some of them had also incited the other workmen to join in this act of obstructing the loyal and willing trammers so that they may be prevented from working. This happened during a strike which was begun on October 20, 1959 by the Colliery Mazdoor sangh to which the thirteen workmen in question belonged.

facts.text: Strike begun on October 20, 1959 by Colliery Mazdoor Sangh, to which the thirteen workmen belonged.

anchor.surface_text: This happened during a strike which was begun on October 20, 1959 by the Colliery Mazdoor sangh to which the thirteen workmen in question belonged. In companysequence the appellant served charge-sheets on the thirteen workmen on November 9, 1959 charging that they physically obstructed the surface trammers on duty at No. 1 and 2 Inclines from performing their duties and companytrolling the movement of the tubs by sitting in-between tramline track and inciting on various dates, thus violating regulation 38  1   b  of the Coal Mines Regulations.

facts.text: Appellant served charge-sheets on the thirteen workmen on November 9, 1959.

anchor.surface_text: In companysequence the appellant served charge-sheets on the thirteen workmen on November 9, 1959 charging that they physically obstructed the surface trammers on duty at No. 1 and 2 Inclines from performing their duties and companytrolling the movement of the tubs by sitting in-between tramline track and inciting on various dates, thus violating regulation 38  1   b  of the Coal Mines Regulations.

facts.text: Charge-sheets charged violation of regulation 38(1)(b) of the Coal Mines Regulations.

anchor.surface_text: charging that they physically obstructed the surface trammers on duty at No. 1 and 2 Inclines from performing their duties and companytrolling the movement of the tubs by sitting in-between tramline track and inciting on various dates, thus violating regulation 38  1   b  of the Coal Mines Regulations. They were asked to explain within 48 hours why disciplinary action should number be taken against them under r. 27  19  and r. 27  20  of the Coal Mines Standing Order.

facts.text: Workmen submitted explanations to charge-sheets.

anchor.surface_text: They were asked to explain within 48 hours why disciplinary action should number be taken against them under r. 27  19  and r. 27  20  of the Coal Mines Standing Order. The workmen submitted their explanations and an inquiry was held by the Welfare Officer of the appellant.

facts.text: Inquiry held by the Welfare Officer of the appellant.

anchor.surface_text: The workmen submitted their explanations and an inquiry was held by the Welfare Officer of the appellant. The Welfare Officer found all the thirteen workmen guilty of the charges framed against them and recommended their dismissal.

facts.text: Welfare Officer found all thirteen workmen guilty and recommended dismissal.

anchor.surface_text: The Welfare Officer found all the thirteen workmen guilty of the charges framed against them and recommended their dismissal. As another reference was pending before this very tribunal in November 1959, the appellant made thirteen applications to the tribunal under s. 33  2   b  of the Act for approval of the action taken.

facts.text: Appellant made thirteen applications to tribunal under s.33(2)(b) for approval in November 1959.

anchor.surface_text: As another reference was pending before this very tribunal in November 1959, the appellant made thirteen applications to the tribunal under s. 33  2   b  of the Act for approval of the action taken. Though the workmen submitted their replies in those proceedings they did number companytest them thereafter, and the tribunal approved of the action taken.

facts.text: Tribunal approved the action taken under s.33(2)(b).

anchor.surface_text: Though the workmen submitted their replies in those proceedings they did number companytest them thereafter, and the tribunal approved of the action taken. Thereafter the present reference was made under S.10 of the Act.

facts.text: Present reference made under s.10 of the Act.

anchor.surface_text: Thereafter the present reference was made under S.10 of the Act. The case put forward by the workmen in-the present reference was that there was numberproper enquiry as the workmen were number given a chance to defend themselves.

facts.text: Workmen claimed no proper enquiry and no chance to defend.

anchor.surface_text: The case put forward by the workmen in-the present reference was that there was numberproper enquiry as the workmen were number given a chance to defend themselves. It was further submitted that the dismissals were numberhing but victimisation pure and simple for trade union activities.

facts.text: Workmen claimed dismissals were victimisation for trade union activities.

anchor.surface_text: It was further submitted that the dismissals were numberhing but victimisation pure and simple for trade union activities. The tribunal apparently held that the inquiry was proper, though it has number said so in so many words in its award.

facts.text: Tribunal held inquiry was proper.

anchor.surface_text: The tribunal apparently held that the inquiry was proper, though it has number said so in so many words in its award. It may be added that it companyld hardly do otherwise, for it had already approved of the action taken on applications made under s. 33  2  b  of the Act.

facts.text: Tribunal held this was a case of victimisation, set aside dismissal, ordered reinstatement within one month without back wages.

anchor.surface_text: But the tribunal held that this was a case of victimisation. It therefore set aside the order of dismissal and ordered the reinstatement of the thirteen workmen within one month of its order becoming operative and ordered that they should be treated as on leave without pay during the period of forced unemployment.

facts.text: Strike was illegal as per Regional Labour Commissioner, Central, Dhanbad.

anchor.surface_text: It was the case of the appellant that the strike was unsatisfied and illegal La it appears that the Regional Labour Commissioner, Central, Dhanbad, agreed with this view of the appellant. It was during such a strike that the misconduct in question took place and the misconduct was that these thirteen workmen physically obstructed other workmen who were willing to work from doing their work by sitting down between the tramlines.

facts.text: Workmen had ten years service or more and good previous record.

anchor.surface_text: It then proceeded to point out that the workmen companycerned had put in ten years service or more and their previous record of service was good. They were important office bearers of the union and some of them were also protected workmen.

facts.text: Supreme Court set aside tribunal's award and upheld dismissal of thirteen workmen.

anchor.surface_text: In the circumstances the tribunals award must be set aside. We therefore allow the appeal.- set aside the award of the tribunal and uphold the dismissal of the thirteen workmen companycerned.

facts.text: Tribunal did not find basic error or violation of natural justice in inquiry.

anchor.surface_text: We have already indicated that the tribunal did number find that there was any basic error or violation of the principles of natural justice in the holding of the inquiry number did it find that the findings of the inquiry officer were perverse or baseless.

facts.text: Workmen were office bearers of the union and some protected workmen.

anchor.surface_text: They were important office bearers of the union and some of them were also protected workmen. It then referred to previous disputes between the appellant and the union of which these workmen were members and was of the view that the union and its leaders were eye-sore to the appellant.

issues.text: Whether the dismissal of the following thirteen workmen of Bhatdee Colliery was justified? If not, to what relief are they entitled and from which date?

anchor.surface_text: to as the Act with reference to the thirteen workmen involved in this appeal in the following terms Whether the dismissal of the following thirteen workmen of Bhatdee Colliery, was justified ? If not, to what relief are they entitled and from which date ?

issues.text: Whether there was proper enquiry as the workmen were not given a chance to defend themselves?

anchor.surface_text: The case put forward by the workmen in-the present reference was that there was numberproper enquiry as the workmen were number given a chance to defend themselves. It was further submitted that the dismissals were numberhing but victimisation pure and simple for trade union activities.

issues.text: Whether the dismissals were an act of unfair labour practice or victimisation?

anchor.surface_text: In the present appeal, the appellant contends that there was numberevidence to justify the conclusion of the tribunal that the dismissals were an act of unfair labour practice or victimisation. We are of opinion that this contention of the appellant must prevail.

issues.text: Whether there is victimisation even if these men were guilty of the offence complained of?

anchor.surface_text: The tribunal however posed a further question as to victimisation in this way But even if assume that these men were guilty of the offence companyplained of, let me pause and companysider if there is victimisation. .It then proceeded to point out that the workmen companycerned had put in ten years service or more

issues.text: Whether the punishment of dismissal was unconscionable or grossly out of proportion to the nature of the offence so as to indicate victimisation?

anchor.surface_text: It referred to a decision of the Calcutta High Court in National Tobacco Company of India Ltd. v. Fourth Industrial Tribunal  1 , where it was held that in a case where the punishment meted out was unconscionable or grossly out of proportion to the nature of the offence that may itself be a ground for holding that the dismissal was an act of victimisation.

holdings.text: The tribunal's prior approval of the dismissals under section 33(2)(b) of the Industrial Disputes Act precludes a subsequent finding that the domestic inquiry was improper.

anchor.surface_text: The tribunal apparently held that the inquiry was proper, though it has number said so in so many words in its award. It may be added that it companyld hardly do otherwise, for it had already approved

holdings.reasoning_summary: Tribunal approved action under s.33(2)(b) without contest; could not later disapprove inquiry.

holdings.text: Where a domestic inquiry has been held properly, an industrial tribunal does not sit in appeal over the findings of the domestic tribunal and can interfere only on limited grounds: want of good faith, basic error, violation of natural justice, perverse or baseless findings, victimisation, or unfair labour practice.

anchor.surface_text: The tribunal was. number unaware of the fact that where a domestic inquiry is held properly. the tribunal does number sit in appeal on the findings of the domestic tribunal and it can only interfere with the punishment inflicted as a result of the domestic inquiry where there is want of good faith or basic error or violation of the principles of natural justice,

holdings.reasoning_summary: Restatement of settled law on scope of tribunal review of domestic inquiries.

holdings.text: The tribunal did not find any basic error, violation of natural justice, or perverse findings in the domestic inquiry.

anchor.surface_text: We have already indicated that the tribunal did number find that there was any basic error or violation of the principles of natural justice in the holding of the inquiry number did it find that the findings of the inquiry officer were perverse or baseless.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Explicitly no such findings by tribunal, consistent with prior s.33(2)(b) approval.

holdings.text: There is no evidence to support the tribunal's finding of victimisation or unfair labour practice; the finding is based merely on conjectures and surmises.

anchor.surface_text: In the present appeal, the appellant companytends that there was numberevidence to justify the companyclusion of the tribunal that the dismissals were an act of unfair labour practice or victimisation. We are of opinion that this companytention of the appellant must prevail.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Appellant's contention accepted; no evidence beyond speculation.

holdings.text: The physical obstruction of willing workmen by sitting between tramlines during an illegal strike constitutes serious misconduct justifying dismissal; the punishment is neither unconscionable nor grossly disproportionate.

anchor.surface_text: This was in our opinion serious misconduct on the part of the thirteen workmen and if it is found-as it has been found-proved punishment of dismissal would be perfectly justified. It cannot therefore

holdings.reasoning_summary: Nature of offence during illegal strike warrants extreme penalty; distinguishes National Tobacco case.

holdings.text: Strained relations between employer and union, or the fact that workmen are office-bearers or protected workmen, does not by itself prove victimisation or grant immunity from dismissal for proved misconduct.

anchor.surface_text: But the fact that the relations between an employer and the union were number happy and the workmen companycerned. were office-bearers or active workers of the union would by itself be numberevidence

holdings.reasoning_summary: Would otherwise give carte blanche to union leaders; requires actual evidence.

holdings.text: A mistake in the written statement regarding additional names for one incident does not render the inquiry findings perverse or evidence victimisation, as charges and findings related to a different incident.

anchor.surface_text: The tribunal therefore was patently wrong in using this mistake as evidence of victimisation. We are therefore of opinion that there is numberevidence worth the name in the present case to support the tribunals finding as to victimisation

holdings.reasoning_summary: Mistake clerical; no charge or finding on disputed incident.

holdings.text: The tribunal's award is set aside; the dismissal of the thirteen workmen is upheld as justified.

anchor.surface_text: In the circumstances the tribunals award must be set aside. We therefore allow the appeal.- set aside the award of the tribunal and uphold the dismissal of the thirteen workmen companycerned.

holdings.reasoning_summary: No valid grounds for interference; inquiry proper, no victimisation, punishment justified.

precedents.citation: National Tobacco Company of India Ltd. v. Fourth Industrial Tribunal  1

anchor.surface_text: National Tobacco Company of India Ltd. v. Fourth Industrial Tribunal  1 , where it was held that in a case where the punishment meted out was unconscionable or grossly out of proportion to the nature of the offence that may itself be a ground for holding that the dismissal was an act of victimisation. It seems to have held that the punishment of dismissal in this case was unconscionable or at any rate grossly out of proportion to the nature of the offence and therefore came to the conclusion that this was a case of victimisation.

anchor.surface_text: We therefore allow the appeal.- set aside the award of the tribunal and uphold the dismissal of the thirteen workmen companycerned.

outcome.relief_summary: Appeal allowed; tribunal's award set aside; dismissal of the thirteen workmen upheld
directions: set aside the award of the tribunal
uphold the dismissal of the thirteen workmen concerned
